set.p: INT BILL & ALICE'S APT - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT

div.stage: It is a week before Christmas. The tree is decorated and Christmas cards stand open everywhere in the comfortable Central Park West apartment.
Settled into the couch in the living room, watching TV, are seven year-old , HELENA, and the BABY-SITTER, a young college girl.
BEDROOM BILL and ALICE HARFORD, an attractive couple in their thirties, are in evening clothes preparing to leave for a party.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: How do I look?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You look great.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: My hair okay?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Perfect.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: You're not even looking at it.

div.stage: Bill kisses her neck.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It's absolutely beautiful. You always look beautiful.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Oh, shut up... OK, let's go.

div.stage: They walk into the living room. The baby sitter gets to her feet.

sp.speaker: BABY-SITTER
sp.p: Oh, you look so-ooo lovely, Mrs. Harford.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Thank you, Roz. (to Helena) All ready for bed?

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Yes, Mommy. I took my bath and brushed my teeth.

set.p: AD-LIBS of praise as BILL and ALICE kiss HELENA goodnight.

sp.speaker: BABY-SITTER
sp.p: What time do you want Helena to go to bed?

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Please, Mommy, can I stay up late tonight and watch the (name of TV show) Ple-eease.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: When is it on?

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Ten-thirty.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Okay, darling, but just for tonight.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Thank you, Mommy.

div.stage: The house intercom rings. BILL goes to answer it.

sp.speaker: DOORMAN
sp.p: Doctor Harford?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: DOORMAN
sp.p: The car is here.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: OK, we'll be right down.

div.stage: Bill returns to sitting room.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: OK the car's here - let's go. (to Baby-sitter) Roz, we might be late tonight but I'll hold the car to take you home.

sp.speaker: BABY-SITTER
sp.p: Oh, that's great, Doctor Harford. Thanks very much.

set.p: AD-LIBS of Good nights and have a good time.
EXT HIRED CAR DRIVE-BY (CPW TO 5TH) - NIGHT (2nd Unit)

sp.speaker: DRIVER
sp.p: Can you sign this, Doctor?

div.stage: The doorman, carrying an umbrella, opens the car door.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Okay, thanks..

sp.speaker: DRIVER
sp.p: Thanks. (handing his card) Just phone about half hour before you want to be picked up.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: OK. Fine.

sp.speaker: DRIVER
sp.p: Have a good evening.

div.stage: BILL and ALICE exit the car and enter the house.
Sound of a dance band off.
Many guests still arriving.
Two ladies seated at a table confirm that Doctor and Mrs Harford are on the invitation roster.
Their coats are taken.

set.p: The hosts, VICTOR ZIEGLER, a fit, sun-tanned, man in his mid-fifties,

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Bill!...Alice!... I'm so glad you could come. It's wonderful to see you both,

set.p: AD-LIBS of further greetings while they shake hands and kiss on both

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: And Alice, my dear, forgive the pitiful understatement but you look totally beautiful.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: And Bill, that osteopath you sent me to? He was wonderful. You should see my serve now.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes, he's the top man in the world.

set.p: ANOTHER FABULOUS ROOM - A LITTLE LATER

div.stage: They stop to admire the 17 foot Christmas tree trimmed with colored lights and antique ornaments.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I don't believe it.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: The guy at the piano. That's Nick Nightingale, I went to medical school with him.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: He's plays pretty good for a doctor.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: He's not a doctor. He dropped out. I'm going to have to say hello to him.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Okay, I'll go and get us some more champagne.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'll see you at the bar.

div.stage: BILL walks over to the bandstand as they finish a set.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nick!.. Nick Nightingale!

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Hey! Bill Harford! What a surprise. How the hell are you?

div.stage: AD LIBS of greetings as they shake hands.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: God, how long has it been?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Ten years?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: And a couple.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: How's life been treating you?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Not too bad. And you've become a pianist.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: My friends call me that.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: And how do you happen to playing here tonight?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: I know my Cole Porter and I work cheap.

div.stage: They both laugh.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: How about you. Still in the doctor business?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You know how it is, once a doctor, always a doctor.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: In my case, never a doctor, never a doctor. You _don't_ know how that is.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I never did understand why you walked away.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: No? It's a nice feeling. I do it a lot.

div.stage: The BAND LEADER comes over and gives NICK a nod and BILL an polite smile.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Okay, we're off again. Listen, if I don't catch you later, I'm down in the Village for the next two weeks, at the Cafe Sonata. Come by if you get a chance.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Cafe Sonata, right. Okay, and listen, it was great seeing you again.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Same here. Take care.

div.stage: The band starts up again.
The ballroom is crowded and BILL starts to make his way around the dance floor to the bar.
ALICE is at the bar waiting for him.
She reaches absently for her champagne glass...
and finds she is holding - or touching - a man's hand.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I think that's my glass.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: I'm absolutely certain of it.

set.p: SZABO is a handsome man, in his mid-forties with a slight Central

div.stage: He drinks slowly from ALICE'S glass and looks directly into her eyes as he does so.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: Did you ever read the Latin poet Ovid on The Art of Love?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Didn't he wind up all by himself, crying his eyes out in some place with a very bad climate.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: But he also had a good time first. A very good time.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: By the way, my name is Sandor Szabo. I'm Hungarian.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Pleased to meet you. My name is Alice. I'm American.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: Would you like to dance, Alice?

div.stage: ALICE notices BILL across the room talking to two beautiful models.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Why not? - Sandor.

set.p: ACROSS THE ROOM - BILL & THE MODELS

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: Nobody likes you? (louder)

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: Nobody likes you, is that the problem?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Put it this way, nobody _wants_ to admit how much they like me. But I'm confident it can still happen.

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: Do you know Nuala Windsor?

div.stage: GAYLE asks, putting her arm around her friend's waist.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nuala...I certainly feel like I do. How do you spell, Nuala?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Is that a Hawaiian name?

sp.speaker: NUALA
sp.p: No, it's an agency name.

div.stage: They all laugh.

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: You were very kind to her once.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Only once? That sounds like an oversight.

sp.speaker: NUALA
sp.p: I was on a shoot, modelling at Rockefeller Center, on a very windy day. You happened to be passing by.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: And you got something in your eye?

sp.speaker: NUALA
sp.p: Just about half of 5th Avenue. You were such a gentleman.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: That can happen when you're in a hurry.

sp.speaker: NUALA
sp.p: You actually had a _handkerchief_ - which was also clean!

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: That's the kind of hero I can be sometimes!

div.stage: ALICE is dancing with the Sandor. He holds her close to him.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: What do you do, Alice?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Well, actually, I'm looking for a job at the moment. I was an editor at a publishing house but they went broke.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: Perhaps I can be of some help. I know a few people in publishing.

div.stage: Alice doesn't reply to this.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: And you're married?

div.stage: ALICE shows him her wedding ring.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: And you're here tonight with your husband?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I am, indeed..

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: How sad.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: But of course I should have guessed that. If you weren't with your husband tonight you wouldn't be so careful.

div.stage: ALICE laughs.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: May I ask why a beautiful woman who could have any man in this room wants to be married?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: You can ask.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: You know why women used to get married, don't you?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Why don't you tell me.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: It was the only way they could lose their virginity's and be free to do what they wanted with other men. The ones they really wanted.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Fascinating.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: Victor and Illona have a fabulous art collection.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: They do, don't they.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: Have you ever seen the Impressionist stuff upstairs?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I don't think so.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: There are a couple of magnificent Bonnards up there.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Are there?

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: Do you like Bonnard?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: Would you like me to show them to you?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Well, maybe not just right now.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: We won't be gone long.

div.stage: ALICE smiles and shakes her head.
BILL AND THE MODELS NUALA slowly leading BILL to the door.

sp.speaker: NUALA
sp.p: Do you know what's so nice about doctors?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Usually a lot less than people think.

sp.speaker: NUALA
sp.p: They look so... knowledgable!

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: They are very knowledgeable - about all sorts of things.

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: But I'll bet they work too hard. I bet they miss out on a lot of fun.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You're absolutely right. Where we going, girls?

sp.speaker: NUALA
sp.p: Where the rainbow ends.

div.stage: BILL slows down a little.

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: Don't you want to go where the rainbow ends?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Do I want to go where the rainbow ends?

div.stage: Before he can answer, a big man who looks like he stepped right out of _The Godfather_ walks up - HARRIS, Ziegler's _personal assistant_.

sp.speaker: HARRIS
sp.p: Excuse me, Doctor Harford. May I trouble you for a moment?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Sure.

sp.speaker: HARRIS
sp.p: Could you spare a minute, please?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What's up?

sp.speaker: HARRIS
sp.p: Could you come with me, please?

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: It's something for Me. Z.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Okay.

sp.speaker: GAYLE
sp.p: Come back soon.

div.stage: The girls blow kisses. Bill smiles.
ALICE AND SZABO DANCING

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: Alice, you're a fascinating woman.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: I'd really like to see you again.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I don't think that would really be a good idea.

sp.speaker: SZABO
sp.p: You _are_ cruel. What about lunch, later this week?

set.p: BILL AND HARRIS - CORRIDORS AND STAIRCASE

div.stage: HARRIS stops in front of a large door and knocks quietly.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Yes?

sp.speaker: HARRIS
sp.p: It's Harris, sir.

div.stage: After a few seconds the key is turned in the lock and the door slowly opens revealing a barefoot ZIEGLER wearing only his pants and undershirt.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Thanks very much for coming up, Bill.

div.stage: He gestures BILL in. HARRIS waits outside.

set.p: A strikingly beautiful, half-naked woman in her late twenties, is

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What happened?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: She OD'd on coke.

div.stage: ZIEGLER gestures to the cocaine paraphernalia on the night table.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: How long has she been like this?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Maybe ten minutes?

div.stage: BILL feels her carotid artery.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Has this happened before?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Not sure, but probably.

div.stage: BILL turns her face to the light of a table lamp to check her pupils.
The woman stirs.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: She's starting to come around.

div.stage: The woman makes a few unintelligible sounds. BILL takes her wrist again and looks at his watch.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good...Well...I don't think there's really anything to worry about. Coke wears off in half an hour or so.

div.stage: ZIEGLER is visibly relieved.
BILL continues to watch her in silence.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Someone should stay with her, though, until she's fully herself again.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Okay.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Some cold towels on her face wouldn't be a bad idea.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Okay.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Anyone here with her to take her home?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: I'll take care of that...She's a friend of the family.

div.stage: Bill nods and watches her for a few moments longer. The he makes moves like he wants to go..

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: She'll be all right, Victor. Okay if I leave the rest to you?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Sure... And listen, Bill, I don't know how to thank you enough for this.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It was nothing. Glad to be of help.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: And, Bill - I know I don't have to say this but I trust this is just between the two of us.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Of course.

div.stage: BALLROOM BILL re-enters the ballroom and looks around for the two models but he doesn't see them.
Then... a woman's arm slips through his.

set.p: He looks down at the wedding-ringed hand.

div.stage: It's ALICE.
She is flushed and glad to have found him.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Haven't I seen you someplace before?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Could be. What's your name again?

div.stage: She kisses him.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Can we go home now?

sp.speaker: V.O.
sp.p: That night they were more blissful in their ardent love than they had been for a long time.

div.stage: SHOTS TO ILLUSTRATE V.O.
Getting up.
Alice and Helena in the kitchen.
Bill in his office with patients.

sp.speaker: V.O.
sp.p: The gray of morning awakened them only too soon.

div.p: And Bill had a number of early appointments.
So the evening hours passed in the predetermined daily routine of work, and the events of the night before began to fade.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: And now, my darling, time for bed. What do you say?

div.stage: HELENA smiles and puts her arms around BILL.
BILL and ALICE kiss her goodnight, turn out the lights and go into the living room.
LIVING ROOM ALICE sighs comfortably.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: So, how do you feel about wrapping some presents?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Kind of negative. We can do it tomorrow.

div.stage: Bill drops down on the couch, picks up the TV controller and starts switching channels.
Alice snuggles up to him.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Anything good on tonight?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Have you got the paper?

div.stage: Alice puts her arms around him.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I don't feel like watching TV.

div.stage: They kiss.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Let's break the law a little first

div.stage: BEDROOM Alice skillfully rolls two joints.
MINUTES LATER Bill and Alice sitting in bed, partly undressed and smoking the joints.
Alice inhales and leans back with an ashtray in her lap. She is high.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: How about the truth game?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Always a bit dangerous with pot.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Isn't that the fun?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm putty in your hands.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Okay, let's start with who were those those two gorgeous women at the party last night?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Don't really know. One of them just started talking to me.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I thought they might be patients?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No such luck. They're models. One of them said I once removed something from her eyes on windy day in Rockefeller Plaza.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Always on the job.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: That's me.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: And what did they want from you this time?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: My body - what else?

div.stage: ALICE doesn't find the remark particularly amusing.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hey, come on - all I did was talk to them... Anyway, who was the guy _you_ were dancing with?

div.stage: BILL is not that interested and just wants to change the subject.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Sandor?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Sandor... Who is he?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: A friend of the Zieglers.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: And what does he do?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I never actually found out?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Rich?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Talked like he was.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: And what did he want?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Sex. Upstairs. Then and there.

div.stage: The pot makes ALICE think this is hilarious.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, I guess that's understandable.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Understandable?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, you're a beautiful woman.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Oh, I see. So does exhaustive research show that every man I meet wants to screw me?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: There might be some exceptions.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Does that mean that all men, with _possibly_ _some_ _exceptions_, want to screw all beautiful women, married or otherwise?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I suppose, basically, yes.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: So does that mean you wanted to screw the two models?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I did say with some exceptions.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: And of course you're an exception?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: How come?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Because I love you.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Any other reasons?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Because we're married.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Any others?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: And because I wouldn't lie to you or hurt you.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: So basically what it comes down to is that you wouldn't screw the two models out of _consideration_ for me, but otherwise you would.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hey, is this thing on Court TV?

div.stage: BILL feigns looking around for cameras.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Why don't you just give me a straight answer?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hey, come on, honey. The pot's making you aggressive.

div.stage: He takes her cigarette and puts it out.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I'm not being aggressive at all - and how about you not putting out my

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Okay. Okay. Okay.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Now try to be honest. When some really great-looking woman comes in to your office to have her tits checked out, don't you ever think about screwing her?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Come on, give me a break. I'm a doctor. It's all very impersonal. And anyway my insurance requires that a nurse is always present.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: You're being evasive. When you're feeling her tits, is it never any more than sheer professionalism?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Basically, that's all it is.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Just basically?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Oh, come on. There are no absolutes in anything.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: No absolutes... Okay. Fine... And does the same thing go for women? While they're having their tits squeezed, do you suppose your lady patients ever wonder what your dick might be like?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Definitely not.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: And why is that?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Because they're too worried about what I might find.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: You know what I mean.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, again. Not most of them.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, I suppose that most women are programmed differently from men

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Oh, yes, I forgot. Millions of years of evolution - right? Men have to put their sperm into as many women as they can, but women stay at home with pretty pink things and take care of the children?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: A bit oversimplified but something like that.

div.stage: A dispirited smile passes over her face.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Oh, if you men only knew.

div.stage: The look in her eyes changes, becoming cool and impenetrable, and BILL allows her hands to slip from his.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: If we knew -? What do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: About what you imagine, my dear.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hey, Alice, hey, look at me... The truth. Is there something you've kept from me?

div.stage: ALICE looks down with a strange smile.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You're just trying to wind me up.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: If you say so.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: If I say so? Wait a minute. I'm not going to let you get away with that... Seriously... Is there's something you haven't told me?

div.stage: ALICE stops short of saying something.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Say it.

div.stage: ALICE nods.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Well, last summer at Cape Cod - I don't suppose you remember one night in the dining room, there was a young Naval officer sitting near us. He was with two other officers.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: As a matter of fact, I don't But what about him?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: The waiter brought him a message during dinner, at which point he left the table?

div.stage: Bill waits for her to continue.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Well...I first saw him that morning in the lobby. He was checking in and he was following the bellboy with his luggage to the elevator.
He glanced at me as he walked past but didn't stop until he had gone a few more steps. Then he turned and looked at me.
He didn't say anything. He didn't smile. In fact, it seemed to me that he scowled. Maybe I did the same thing.

div.stage: ALICE stops for a moment.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I was very stirred by him. That whole day I lay on the beach, lost in dreams.

div.stage: She stops.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Go on.

div.stage: ALICE thinks about how to continue.
BILL stares at her.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: That afternoon you and I made love and talked about our future, and our child.
Later we were sitting on the balcony and he passed below us without looking up.
Just the sight of him stirred me deeply and I thought if he wanted me, I could not have resisted. I thought I was ready to give up you, the child, my whole future.
And yet at the same time - if you can understand it - you were dearer to me than ever, and I stroked your forehead and kissed your hair, and at that moment my love for you was both tender and sad.
At dinner I wore a white rose and you said I was very beautiful. It might not have been just an accident that he and his friends sat near us.
He didn't look up but I actually considered getting up, walking over to him and like someone in a movie, saying, 'Here I am, my love, for whom I have waited - take me.'
Well, it was about then that the waiter brought him the envelope. He read it, turned pale, said goodbye to his friends - and glancing at me mysteriously, he left the room.

div.stage: ALICE stops for a moment.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I barely slept that night and woke up the next morning very agitated. I didn't know whether I was afraid that he had left or that he might still be there... But by dinner I realised he was gone and I breathed a sigh of relief.

div.stage: Long silence

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: And if he hadn't left?

div.stage: Alice doesn't reply.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I don't know.

div.stage: BILL doesn't say anything but there is a scornful expression around his mouth.
The phone rings.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hello?...Oh... When did they call?... No, I have the address...If they call again say I'm on my way.

div.stage: He hangs up the phone and starts to put on his shoes.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Lou Nathanson just died.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Oh, that's too bade. But you were expecting that, weren't you?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes..

div.stage: Bill starts to get dressed.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I have to go over there for a while.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Now?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I have to show my face.

div.stage: BILL silently getting dressed.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Obviously, it was a mistake to have told you.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Not at all.. We must always tell each other everything.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: It was the pot.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It doesn't really matter. Nothing happened. Just a passing fancy.

div.stage: INT MARION'S LOBBY Bill walks to the elevator
INT MARION's PRIVATE ELEVATOR LOBBY Bill exits elevator and find's her door ajar. He knocks softly and enters without waiting for a reply.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Marion?

div.stage: He walks through the quiet apartment.
MASTER BEDROOM The body of LOU NATHANSON lies on a large bed with an oxygen cylinder and other medical paraphernalia on tables on each side of the bed.
MARION, the dead man's daughter, a pretty girl in her late twenties, sits at the foot of the bed, exhausted, her arms hanging limply at her side.
She starts to get up but BILL stops her with a movement from his hand, and she merely greets him with a nod, her eyes large and sad.
BILL moves to the head of the bed and mechanically places his hands on the forehead of the dead man and on his arms.
He shakes his head a couple of times and his shoulders drop with a slight expression of regret.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I hope his last moments were peaceful.

div.stage: Marion gives him a despairing look.
He puts his hands in his pockets and his eyes wander about the room until they finally rest again on Marion.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, Marion, at least you weren't entirely unprepared for this.

div.stage: She holds out her hand to him. He takes it sympathetically.
Marion sighs, woefully.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Dad seemed pretty good today. Around nine o'clock he said he felt like taking a nap. So I went into the living room to watch television. I don't think I was out of his room for more than half-an-hour.

div.stage: Marion starts to weep.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: When I went back, at first I though he was still asleep... The I realized he wasn't breathing... I did everything you had told me but.. he was....

div.stage: She can't bring herself to say, dead, and she shakes her head, despairingly.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: I called the emergency people... But when they got here they just said he was...dead and asked whether I wanted them to take him away?

div.stage: She breaks down sobbing.
BILL draws up a chair and sits down opposite her.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Marion, from what you've said, it sounds like your father died in his sleep. He wouldn't have suffered.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Oh, God...I hope not... I've been so afraid of the actual... dying business... But he made it _so_ _easy_, just as he tried to make everything else in my life easy.

div.stage: BILL takes her hands.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Have you notified any of your relatives?

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: I phoned Carl - my fiancee.

div.stage: She does not look BILL straight in the eye when she says, fiancee/

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: He's going to make some calls for me and then he's coming over.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Oh, that's good.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: I think you've met Carl here a few times? We're planning to get married in April.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Oh, that's wonderful. I'm very happy for you.

div.stage: They sit for a few moments without speaking.

sp.speaker: V.O.
sp.p: I certainly do remember Carl. So she's going to marry him, Bill thought to himself. I wonder why? She surely can't be in love with him. He's nothing to look at, and he hasn't got any money... He's just an assistant in professor of something or other... But then it's none of my business. Still... if she were my mistress, her hair would be less dry and her lips would be fuller and redder.

div.stage: Marion suddenly starts to talk.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Dad had so many worries and disappointments. My mother was never well... And my _brother_...he was such a disappointment... I don't even know where he is. The last we heard from him was from some small town in Mexico. I can't even remember where.
[POSSIBLE MISSING PAGE]

div.stage: In spite of himself, BILL places his hand on her head, caressing it. He feels her body begin to tremble and her sobs become louder and finally quite unrestrained.
All at once, she slips down from her chair and kneels in front of him, clasping his legs with her arms and pressing her face into them.
She looks up at him with large eyes, wild with grief, and whispers ardently:

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: I don't want to leave here... Even if you never return... Even if I am never to see you again... I want, at least, to live near you.

div.stage: BILL looks touched rather than surprised.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Please - get up, Marion.

div.stage: He says this softly, and bending down he gently raises her up.
He glances at the dead man on the bed and only puts his arms around her in a very hesitant embrace and kisses her on the forehead.
At the same time, without knowing why, a sense of anger wells up against ALICE.
_Jealous fantasy image of Alice and the Naval officer._
The door bell rings.
He hastily kisses Marion's cheek, as if in gratitude, and goes to the door.

set.p: It's CARL standing there - a very ordinary looking man with an

div.stage: The two men greet each other much more cordially than is called for by their actual state of acquaintance.
They walk to the bedroom and CARL has an embarrassed look at the deceased.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.p: Oh, my poor, dear Marion. I am so sorry.

div.stage: He puts his arms around her.
BILL goes into the next room to write out the death certificate.
When he finishes, he returns to the bedroom where the engaged couple sit, hand in hand, by the bed of the dead man.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.p: I'll get it.

div.stage: While he is out of the room, Marion, with her eyes on the floor, says, almost inaudibly:

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: I love you.

div.stage: BILL merely pronounces her name tenderly.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Marion.

div.stage: CARL returns with Marion's UNCLE and AUNT and aunt, whose presence gives BILL the opportunity to make his goodbyes and leave.
At the door.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.p: I hope we'll see you soon.

sp.speaker: DOORMAN
sp.p: Taxi?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No thanks. I think I'll walk for a bit.

div.stage: A tramp lies full length on a bench wrapped in newspapers with his hat over his face.

sp.speaker: V.O.
sp.p: The image of the tramp made him think of the dead man he had just left, and he shuddered and felt slightly nauseated at the thought that decay and decomposition had already begun their work in the body he just left.

He was glad he was still alive and in all probability that these ugly things were still far removed from him, and that he was, in fact, still in the prime of life, had a beautiful wife and could have several women in addition, if he wanted to, although doing so would require more free time than he had.

div.stage: BILL notices a group of rowdy college boys coming towards him, six of them taking up the whole walkway.
He moves aside to keep out of their way.
But as they pass, one of them, a tall boy with an open overcoat, deliberately bumps into him with his raised elbow.
BILL involuntarily stops.
The tall student takes two more steps and turns.
They glare at each other for a moment with only a short distance separating them.
Suddenly, BILL turns around again and walks.
He hears a short laugh behind him.
He wants to turn around and fight but he feels his heart beating strangely.

sp.speaker: V.O.
sp.p: Had he become a coward, he asked himself, and noticed his knees were shaking a little bit. Ridiculous! Why should he get involved in a street fight with some drunken college student who had five friends with him.

div.p: He, a man of thirty-five, a practising physician, a married man and father of a child. He might wind up in the hospital or worse and tomorrow be in the same position as the man he just left.. Then he thought about his profession? There were dangers lurking there, too, everywhere and at all times - except that one usually forgets about them.

set.p: EXT STREET - ON WAY DOMINO - NIGHT

sp.speaker: V.O.
sp.p: Surely, it had been nothing but common sense to avoid a ridiculous fight with the student... but if he ever meet the Naval officer with whom Alice...

set.p: JEALOUS FANTASY IMAGE - ALICE AND NAVAL OFFICER

sp.speaker: V.O.
sp.p: But what insanity! After all, nothing happened... What was he thinking about?... But then, wasn't it really just as bad as if she had actually fucked him - she might just as well have. Wasn't it even worse, in a way. What a joy it would be to teach _him_ a lesson.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Hi.

div.stage: BILL slows down and looks at her. She is very pretty with dark red lips.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hi.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: How're you doing?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Fine. How are you doing?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: I'm doing great...Listen, how would you like to have a little fun?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm sorry?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Have a little fun. Come inside with me? I just live over there.

div.stage: She points to a nearby doorway.
BILL a little off balance.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Come inside with you?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Yes. It's a lot nicer than it is out here.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Do you live there?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: By yourself?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: I have a roommate but she's not home.

div.stage: She gently takes his arm.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: It's okay - no one will bother us.

div.stage: BILL smiles, uncertainly.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Really, it's okay. Come on.

div.stage: BILL allows himself to be led to the door.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Come on.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Should we talk about the money?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: How does sixty sound?

div.stage: BILL nods, a little uncomfortably.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Sixty. Sounds good.

div.stage: DOMINO laughs.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: I don't keep track of the time.

div.stage: She unlocks the door and they go inside.

set.p: It's a clean, reasonably tidy, ex cold-water railway flat.

div.stage: The girl smiles sweetly, and walks ahead of BILL into the narrow bedroom where there is a neatly made king-size bed without a bedspread..

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: By the way, what's your name?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Domino.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Domino. That's an unusual name.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Well, it's my, uh...professional name.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: And what's your name?

div.stage: Bill hesitates.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Bill.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Hi, Bill.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hi, Domino.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Would you like a drink or some grass?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No thanks. I'm fine.

div.stage: She puts on some music.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nice little place.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Yes, it's okay.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Is this really your place?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: That's the second time you asked.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, it just that I was under the impression that most girls didn't use their own apartment - too much hassle.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: That's true but I don't do this that much.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Oh, how's that?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: I only work when I get too far behind with my student loan.

div.stage: BILL is a little surprised.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What are you school are you going to?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: NYU.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: NYU. What are you studying?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Sociology.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good sociology department?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Pretty good. Ever hear of Pearlstein and Johnson?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: To be honest, I'm not much into sociology.

div.stage: She slowly starts to undress.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: What do you do?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm a doctor?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: A doctor?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: GP?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: My father's a GP.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No kidding? I hope I don't know him.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: He practises in New Jersey.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: New Jersey..

div.stage: She steps out of her panties and tosses them on the table.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Listen, I know it's a little late for this but do you mind if I ask how old you are?

div.stage: She stands naked before him with her arms outstretched.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: How old do you think?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, to be honest, I would have said sixteen or seventeen but obviously if you're going to college... eighteen?

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Nineteen.

div.stage: She puts her arms around his neck again and gazes into his eyes.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Well, shall we?

div.stage: _Bleep-bleep_.
BILL's cellular phone.
_Bleep-bleep_
He fumbles in his pockets for the phone and DOMINO has to get off his lap for him to get it out.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hello?

div.stage: It's ALICE.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hi, honey. Yes, everything's okay... I'm not sure... We're waiting for some relatives to show up... It could be late... No, don't wait up. Can't really talk... Okay, as soon as I can... Same here.

div.stage: He disconnects and puts the phone back in his pocket.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Was that Mrs Doctor Bill?

div.stage: BILL thinks for a moment and nods. Then he sighs and gets to his feet.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: You have to go.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm afraid so.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: What a shame.

div.stage: He gets out his wallet and starts to count out sixty dollars.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Oh, look, you don't have to...

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, that's all right, he says.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Really. It's okay.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, no. Listen, we need more good sociologists.

div.stage: They both laugh.

sp.speaker: DOMINO
sp.p: Okay but you've got a raincheck.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: That's deal.

set.p: EXT STREET TO CAFE SONATA - NIGHT

sp.speaker: V.O.
sp.p: Where shall I go now, he asked himself? The obvious thing was home to bed. But he couldn't persuade himself to do that.
He thought of going back to the girl but that somehow seemed ridiculous now.
He was overcome with a sense that he was moving farther and farther away from his everyday existence into a completely different world.

div.stage: By the chance, he passes a small nightclub, Cafe Sonata, and notices Nick Nightingale's name and photograph outside.
He stops and looks at it.
The DOORMAN drifts over.

sp.speaker: DOORMAN
sp.p: The band's about to wind up but they're still serving.

div.stage: BILL nods and goes in.
The place is about a quarter full. BILL sits down at a table near the band.
Nick sees him and winks.
BILL gestures hello, orders a beer.
The band finishes their last number and take a perfunctory bow to a scattering of applause.
NICK comes over to the table.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Hey, Bill!

set.p: They shake hands and ad-libs of greetings.

div.stage: The WAITER swoops in with BILL's beer.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What are you drinking?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Scotch and soda.

div.stage: The WAITER nods and hurries off.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: So what brings you out at this hour?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Just happened to be passing by. I have a patient in the neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Do you live in the Village?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, we've got an apartment on Central Park West.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: You're married?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nine years.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: That was the great looking woman you were dancing with at the party?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Lucky man.

div.stage: BILL nods.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Any kids?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: An eight year old daughter. How about you?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: I've got a wife and four boys in Seattle.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: That's great. So is this your band?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: No, I'm just filling in.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Who do you normally play with?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Anybody. Anywhere. As a matter of fact, I've got another gig later tonight.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You're playing somewhere else _tonight_?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: They only get started there about two

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: In the village?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: I don't actually know the address yet.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: How come?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: It's in a different place every time, and I only get it about an hour or so beforehand.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: A different place every time?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: So far.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What's the big mystery?

div.stage: Nick opens his palms in a parody of innocence.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: I just play the piano.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What kind of a function is it?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: What kind of a function is it?... Well, to be completely honest, it's not easy to describe.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: But you've worked there before?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: And it's not easy to describe?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: I play blindfolded.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: I play blindfolded.

div.stage: Something near the entrance door attracts Nick's attention.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Back in a minute.

div.stage: He walks to the front window of the club and looks out into the snowy street. He doesn't see what he's looking for and returns.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Sorry about that. I'm supposed to meet somebody here.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: With the address?

div.stage: Nick shrugs, meaning, yes.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Listen, you're putting me on about that blindfolded business, aren't you.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: No, that's the truth. They're very strict about that.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: This is getting curiouser and curiouser.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Maybe so, but listen, I was sworn to secrecy, and please, just forget I said anything at all about it.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nick, you can trust me. I won't say a word about this to anyone but since you've told me this much, you can't stop now.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: No, really, this is not a joke. I'm not saying anything else.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nick, you can't do this to me. I'll wonder about this for the rest of my life. Trust me.

div.stage: NICK is very uncomfortable about this but is also dying to talk about it.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Okay, well this is just between us.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Absolutely.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Well...first of all, although I am blindfolded I can of course still hear...and the sounds...

div.stage: NICK closes his eyes and lets the provocative innuendo sink in.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: _And_...the last time the blindfold wasn't tied on that well.

div.stage: NICK also lets that sink in.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Bill...I've seen a few things in my life but never anything like this... And I have never seen such women.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What does it cost to get into this place?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Forget it.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What do you mean, forget it.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Forget it.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Look, I don't care what it costs.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: It's not a matter of money. These people aren't interested in money. It's a completely closed affair.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: _These_ _people_. Who are _these_ _people_?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Put it this way - if I knew their names it would be worth more than my life to say them out loud.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nick, don't you think you might just be over-dramatising this a little bit? There must be some way you can get me in.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: It would be too dangerous.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Dangerous?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: These are not people you fuck with - if you'll pardon the pun.

div.stage: Nick sees someone looking through the plate glass window.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: I'll be right back.

div.stage: He gets up and hurries outside to the street.
BILL watches him through the window, hunched up against the cold, stamping his feet up and down, talking to a man and writing something down.
Nick returns blowing on his hands.
Bill gives him and inquiring look.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Was that the address?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: And the password.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Password?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Yes. You can't get in without the password and they change it every time. And. listen, I'm going to have to get weaving pretty soon.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nick, you son-of-a-bitch, you know you are definitely going to have to take me with you tonight. You know that, don't you.

div.stage: Nick sighs and shakes his head.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Look, I'll tell you what - you give me the password and the address and I'll go there by myself. There won't be the slightest connection with you, whatsoever.

div.stage: NICK squirms.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Look, even if I were crazy enough to do that, you couldn't get in the way you're dressed, anyway.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Everyone there is always masked and in costume.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Masked and in costume?

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Always.

div.stage: Bill looks at his watch.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Okay. Point taken. _But_ there's a possibility I know a place that might still be open.

sp.speaker: NICK
sp.p: Bill, you're out of your mind. No costume place would be open at this time of night.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Look, Nick, what the hell. Just give me a chance. Let me try. If I can't get the gear I'll forget about the whole thing. Scouts honour.

div.stage: NICK looks ready to give in.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Okay?

div.stage: NICK sighs in resignation.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Okay. So, let me have the address and the password, and tell me what kind of costume I need?

set.p: EXT BUSY GREENWICH VILLAGE STREET - NIGHT

div.stage: The place is closed.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Shit.

div.stage: He thinks for a moment, pays the driver and gets out.
He notices a sign that says: "In case of emergency ring apartment 3."
He looks up and sees a light on in the apartment above the store.
He rings the bell for apartment 3, which has the name, Gibson..
After a couple of rings, a voice comes over the intercom.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Yes, what is it?

div.stage: BILL talks to the TV security camera.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Mister Gibson?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Mister Gibson, I'm very sorry to disturb you at this hour. I'm a Doctor. My name is Harford. I need to see you. It's important.

div.stage: Bill holds up his New York State Medical Board card to the doorway TV security camera.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Somebody hurt?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No one's hurt but it's important.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What kind of important?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It would really be better if I could come upstairs for a moment and talk to you.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: You better come back tomorrow.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Mr. Gibson, tomorrow will be too late. I really need to see you now. It won't take long.

div.stage: Silence.
Then the door buzzer sounds.
BILL pushes open the door and goes upstairs two at a time.
A door opens on the chain and a man in his fifties, wearing flannel pyjamas and a heavy bathrobe, who has the looks and manner of a road-company ham actor peers out.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Mr. Gibson?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Yes.

div.stage: BILL holds up his New York State medical card again.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good evening, Mister Gibson. This is my New York State Medical Board card, just so you know who I am.

div.stage: Gibson looks at the card and at BILL.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Okay, so you're Doctor Harford. What's this all about?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Mister Gibson, you may not find it that easy to understand the urgency of this, but basically, uhm... I need...a costume and a tux..

div.stage: Gibson stares at him in disbelief.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: You need a costume and a tux?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I'm sorry, but do you honestly expect me to open my shop for you, at this hour?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I can imagine how this may seem to you, Mister Gibson, and I am prepared to pay an extra two hundred dollars for the inconvenience.

div.stage: Gibson doesn't reply.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: How does that sound to you?

div.stage: Judging from his expression, this sounds pretty good to Mr. Gibson.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Okay, now let me get this straight. You want a tuxedo, a black monk's cassock and a mask that completely covers your face?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: That's it.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I have to tell you doctor, I've had some very strange requests in my day and this is certainly one of them.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It's for a good cause.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Okay, you're the doctor.

div.stage: GIBSON chuckles at his own witticism.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Now, let me get this straight. You want a tuxedo, a monks cassock and a mask that completely covers your face?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: That's it.

div.stage: Suddenly BILL hears the clink of glasses from somewhere ahead of him.
GIBSON flips a light switch.
A light come on in a little office at the end of the passage.
The desk is covered with plates, glasses and bottles.
Two JAPANESE MEN, wearing blonde female wigs, naked except for Japanese kimonos, spring up from their chairs besides the desk.

set.p: At the same moment, the semi-naked figure of a graceful GIRL

div.stage: GIBSON rushes forward with long strides, reaches across the desk and grabs one of the blond wigs.
Simultaneously, the young GIRL, maybe fourteen, wriggles out from under the desk and runs along the passage to BILL who catches her in his arms.
GIBSON drops the wig and grabs the two kimono garbed men.
At the same time he calls out to BILL.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Hold on to that girl for me, please.

div.stage: The GIRL presses against BILL as if now sure of her protection. Her pretty little face covered with powder and a smile of impish desire in her eyes.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Gentlemen, you will stay here while I call the police.

sp.speaker: KIMONO 1
sp.p: Gibson, have you gone mad?

sp.speaker: KIMONO 2
sp.p: We were invited by the young lady.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: You will have to explain this. Couldn't you see the girl is unbalanced?

div.stage: Then GIBSON he turns to BILL.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Sorry to keep you waiting.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: That's okay.

div.stage: BILL looks down with fascination at the GIRL, who looks up at him with alluring and childlike eyes, as if spellbound.
The two KIMONO MEN start to argue with each other in Japanese..
GIBSON turns to BILL.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I'm sorry, did you say a brown or black cassock?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Black.

sp.speaker: YOUNG GIRL
sp.p: No. You must give this gentleman a cloak lined with ermine and a doublet of red silk.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Don't you budge from there.
(to Bill) What size are you?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I take a 38 jacket.

div.stage: GIBSON picks up a brown monk's cassock hanging nearby and holds it up for BILL'S approval.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: This will fit you.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Fine.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Okay, let's go and try on the tux..

div.stage: The two Japanese men are still in the glass partitioned office.
_GIBSON locks them in._

sp.speaker: KIMONO 1
sp.p: Gibson, this is preposterous!! You will have to let us out at once.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I'm afraid that's out of the question, gentlemen. This is now a police matter. You will kindly wait here until I return.

set.p: Ad-libs of further protest from the two men

div.stage: The girl skips lightly up the stairs ahead of them.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Now go to bed at once, you depraved creature. I'll talk to you as soon as I've settled with those two.

div.stage: The girl gives BILL a sad shake of her head and exits.

set.p: INT FRONT OF COSTUME SHOP - A LITTLE LATER

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Okay - that's a hundred and fifty for the rental. Three hundred deposit. And the two hundred inconvenience money. That's six hundred and fifty bucks..

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Okay.

div.stage: BILL hands him his credit card and his driver's license.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I'd prefer cash.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Sorry, I don't carry that kind of money.

div.stage: Gibson takes the credit card.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Thanks. And - by the way - I hope you wont be too hard on the child.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I'm sorry doctor but I'm not sure what business it is of yours.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, it's just that I first heard you say the girl was unbalanced, and then you called her depraved. Those things are a little contradictory.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Well, aren't insanity and depravity the same in the eyes of God?

div.stage: The last thing BILL wants right now is to get into an argument with GIBSON, so he replies in his most professional manner.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, in any event, there _are_ things that can be done that might help the situation. Maybe we can have another talk about it tomorrow.

div.stage: Gibson laughs mockingly without uttering a sound.

set.p: EXT STREET OUTSIDE COSTUME SHOP - NIGHT

div.stage: He checks at a slip of paper with the address on it.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: How do you feel about going out to Sands Point Long Island?

div.stage: The driver makes a face.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: How about twenty bucks over the meter?

sp.speaker: CAB DRIVER
sp.p: I'll have to come back empty.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: How's fifty?

sp.speaker: CAB DRIVER
sp.p: Fifty's good.

set.p: EXT VARIOUS TAXI DRIVE-BYS - NIGHT (2ND UNIT)

sp.speaker: V.O.
sp.p: Bills Thoughts: Variations of, "I must be mad."

set.p: EXT LONG ISLAND MANSION ROAD - NIGHT

div.stage: INT CAB BILL looking out for the house.

set.p: Up ahead, he sees a stretch-limo with darkened windows pulling into

div.stage: As they drive slowly past the gates, BILL sees a sign that says, 'Bletchly Manor'.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Okay, driver - that's the place. Stop a little way down the road.

div.stage: The car comes to a stop.
The meter says $75.50
BILL takes out his wallet.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Okay, here's eighty dollars and...

set.p: BILL carefully tears a hundred-dollar bill in half and gives one part to

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: ...I promised you fifty bucks over the meter but I'll make it a hundred if you wait for me. Let the meter run and you'll get the other half plus the meter when I come back... Okay?

div.stage: The driver gives BILL a wary look.

sp.speaker: CAB DRIVER
sp.p: How long will you be?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: That's the thing - I'm not sure. I could be ten minutes. I could be an hour or so. But look, I'm leaving all my stuff in the back. Okay?

set.p: The cab driver takes half of the torn hundred-dollar bill.

sp.speaker: CAB DRIVER
sp.p: Okay.

div.stage: BILL gets out of the cab, puts on the monk's cassock, throws his coat over his shoulders and walks back to the gates.
Security cameras look at him.
The road leading to the Manor House curves away into a small wood which covers the house.
BILL rings a bell at the side of the gate and two men promptly come out of the gate house.

sp.speaker: GATEMAN 1
sp.p: Good morning, sir.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good morning.

sp.speaker: GATEMAN 1
sp.p: Can we be of any help you?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I suppose you'd like the password?

sp.speaker: GATEMAN 1
sp.p: If you wouldn't mind, sir.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Fidelio Rainbow..

sp.speaker: GATEMAN 1
sp.p: Thank you, sir.

div.stage: The gate is opened.

sp.speaker: GATEMAN 1
sp.p: Is that your taxi down there, sir?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Uh - yes. Yes - my chauffeur came down with the flu at the last minute.

sp.speaker: GATEMAN 1
sp.p: The cabby could have driven you right to the door.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Listen, I'm lucky I got here at all. The guy's straight from Bulgaria.

div.stage: Bill laughs uncomfortably without getting a penny's change from the men.

sp.speaker: GATEMAN 1
sp.p: If you'd like to get in the car, sir. We'll run you up to the house.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Okay. Thanks.

div.stage: They get into the car.
Gateman 2 remains at the gate.
INT CAR Bill sits silently next to the driver.

set.p: POV - THE LONG ISLAND - MANOR HOUSE - NIGHT

div.stage: INT CAR

sp.speaker: GATEMAN 1
sp.p: This might be a good time to put on your mask, sir.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Oh, yes. Of course.

div.stage: BILL takes the mask from his pocket and puts it on.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Thanks.

div.stage: He walks up the stone steps and the front doors are opened before he reaches them.
INT HOUSE BILL enters a large, candlelit, mirrored vestibule where two servants in black suits, their faces covered by grey masks, whisper in unison:

sp.speaker: SERVANTS
sp.p: Password?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Fidelio Rainbow.

sp.speaker: SERVANT 1
sp.p: Thank you, sir.

div.stage: One of them takes his coat, while the other opens a door.
BILL enters a long room, dimly lit with candles, with high ceilings and walls covered with black silk.
A line of mirrored doors on each side run the length of the room.
There are about fifty men and women dressed as monks and nuns, their faces completely covered by masks.
Gently swelling strains of Italian liturgical music comes from an organ playing somewhere.
As his eyes become accustomed to the dim light, BILL sees that the women are naked beneath the full-length, black veils that flow down from their head bands.
His eyes wander from voluptuous bodies to slender bodies, from delicate to richly developed figures, and he is filled with inexpressible desire.
Occasionally, eyes turn towards him but immediately look away as soon as he notices them.
A monk brushes against him and nods a greeting, but from behind the mask BILL sense a searching and penetrating glance.
A strange, heavy perfume, as of southern gardens, pervades the room.
Again an arm brushes against him, but this time it is that of a nun. Her face is fully masked, and like the others, naked under the black transparent lace of her veil.

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: You don't belong here. There's still a chance for you to get away.

div.stage: BILL is momentarily unnerved by this but he is also completely captivated by the beauty and sensuality of this woman.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm terribly sorry but I think you've mistaken me for someone else.

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: Please don't be foolish about this. You must leave at once.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Who are you?

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: It doesn't matter. You must go.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Will you come with me?

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: That's impossible.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Impossible?

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: Impossible.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Is there someplace else here we could go?

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: Absolutely not. Please believe me, if you are discovered it will go hard with you.

div.stage: BILL moves closer to her but she steps back.

sp.speaker: ANOTHER WOMAN
sp.p: What's the matter. Why don't you dance?

div.stage: BILL sees two men watching him from another corner and suspects that this woman has been sent to put him to the test.
He smiles.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I would love to dance.

div.stage: But just at that moment, THE WOMAN returns.
She pretends that she has just noticed him and says in a voice that can be heard by the two men.

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: Returned at last. (she laughs) All your efforts are useless. I know you.

div.stage: Then turning to the other woman she whispers:

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: Let me have him first - just for a while.

div.stage: The other woman smiles agreement, and with a light step goes to join the two men who have been watching.

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: Don't ask any questions, and don't be surprised at anything. I have tried to lead them astray but you can't fool them for much longer. Go before it is too late, - and be careful that no one follows you. No one must know who you are. There would be no more peace for you. Go!

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: [illegible]?

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: There is no way.

div.stage: He takes her hand and draws her closer to him.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I must see you again.

div.stage: She whispers, despairingly

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: Go.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Is there no way I can ever see you again.

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: No. We must never meet again. It could cost your life and mine.

div.stage: Just at that moment, a tall man stops before them, and with a slight bow, courteous but imperative, says:

sp.speaker: TALL MAN
sp.p: Will you dance with me?

div.stage: THE WOMAN hesitates but the TALL MAN puts his arm around her waist and leads her away the adjoining room.
A moment later, a voice whispers behind BILL.

sp.speaker: ELEGANT MAN
sp.p: Password!

div.stage: BILL turns around and sees two men.

set.p: One, heavy-set, the other, slim and elegant.

sp.speaker: ELEGANT MAN
sp.p: Password!

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Fidelio Rainbow.

sp.speaker: ELEGANT MAN
sp.p: That's right, sir. That's the password for admittance, but may I ask what is the password for the house?

div.stage: BILL is stuck. He takes a deep breath..

sp.speaker: ELEGANT MAN
sp.p: Won't you be kind enough to tell me the password of the house?

div.stage: This time it sounds like a threat.
BILL can't think of anything to say. He shakes his head and shrugs.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Sorry. It looks like I must have forgotten it.

div.stage: The elegant man walks to the middle of the room and raises his hand.
Everything gradually comes to a stop.
Blindfolded, Nick stops playing when someone places a hand on his shoulder and whispers something to him.
With all eyes on him, the two men walk back to BILL.

sp.speaker: ELEGANT MAN
sp.p: The password, sir! I must demand that you give it.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Look, I'm terribly sorry but I've told you, I must have forgotten it.

sp.speaker: ELEGANT MAN
sp.p: That's unfortunate. For here it doesn't matter whether you have forgotten it or if you never knew it.

div.stage: The rest of the men slowly gather around BILL.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, I seem to owe you all an apology.

sp.speaker: ELEGANT MAN
sp.p: It is too late for apologies.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, be that as it may, you have my most sincere regrets for not remembering the second password.

sp.speaker: ELEGANT MAN
sp.p: I'm afraid this is not a question of regret but of _expiation_.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, you must excuse me now. I am leaving.

sp.speaker: ELEGANT MAN
sp.p: I'm afraid that is no longer possible.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Gentlemen, don't you think this farce has gone far enough?

div.stage: BILL looks for a way out but no one makes way for him.

sp.speaker: ELEGANT MAN
sp.p: You will kindly remove your mask.

div.stage: BILL looks around at the masked faces surrounding him.

sp.speaker: ELEGANT MAN
sp.p: Please remove your mask.

div.stage: BILL slowly removes his mask and puts it in his pocket.

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: I am ready to redeem him.

div.stage: There is a murmur of surprise in the room.
THE WOMAN reaches for the veil, which is wrapped around her head, face and neck and unwinds it with a wonderful circular movement.
It sinks to the floor, leaving her naked, her dark hair falling in great profusion over her shoulders, breasts and hips.

sp.speaker: ELEGANT MAN
sp.p: You are ready to redeem him?

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: Yes, I am.

div.stage: There is a low gasp from the assemblage.

sp.speaker: ELEGANT MAN
sp.p: You know what you're taking upon yourself in doing this?

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: Yes.

div.stage: Another murmur from the room.
The elegant man turns back to BILL.

sp.speaker: ELEGANT MAN
sp.p: You are free. Leave this house at once. But first I must warn you that if you make any further inquiries or inform anyone about what you have seen here tonight, there will be the most serious consequences for yourself and your family. Do you understand that?

div.stage: BILL doesn't reply immediately.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: How is this woman to redeem me?

sp.speaker: ELEGANT MAN
sp.p: That has nothing to do with you.

div.stage: BILL shakes his head.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I can't let this woman pay for me.

sp.speaker: ELEGANT MAN
sp.p: You would be unable, in any case, to change her fate. When a promise has been made here there is no turning back.

sp.speaker: THE WOMAN
sp.p: _Go! You cannot save me._

div.stage: As she says this, she tears off the mask, allowing BILL a momentary glimpse of her face.
Then he is seized by irresistible arms and pushed out.
BILL, now changed back into his own clothes, enters his apartment.
Everyone is asleep.
He goes into his study and locks the costume and tux in a closet.
In order not to wake ALICE, he undresses before going into the bedroom.
BEDROOM ALICE is asleep, lying with her arms folded under her head
Her lips are half open and painful shadows surround them.
It is a face BILL does not know.
He bends down over her, and at once her forehead becomes lined with furrows, as though someone had touched it, and her features seem strangely distorted.
Suddenly, still in her sleep, she laughs so shrilly that he becomes alarmed.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Alice.

div.stage: She laughs again, as if in answer, in a strange, almost uncanny manner.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Alice?

div.stage: She opens her eyes, slowly and with difficulty.
She stares at him, as though she does not recognise him.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Alice?

div.stage: As she wakes up, an expression of fear, even of terror comes into her eyes.
Half awake, and seemingly in despair, she raises her arms.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What's the matter?

div.stage: ALICE stares at him, still frightened.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Alice, it's me.

div.stage: ALICE breathes deeply, tries to smile, drops her arms on the blanket.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Is it morning yet?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It will be very soon. It's a little past four o'clock. I've just come home.

div.stage: She nods but barely seems to have heard or understood him.
She stares into space, as though she can see through him.
He bends over and touches her forehead.
She shudders slightly.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What's the matter?

div.stage: She shakes her head slowly and he passes his hand gently over her hair.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Alice, you laughed so strangely. What's the matter?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I've been dreaming.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What have you been dreaming?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Oh, so much, I can't quite remember.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Perhaps if you try.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: It was all so confused - and I'm tired. You must be tired, too.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Not really. I don't think I'll go to bed at all. You know, sometimes when I come home so late it's better to just go straight to work.

div.stage: ALICE nods without interest.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: But why don't you tell me about your dream?

div.stage: He smiles a little artificially.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: You really ought to lie down and take a little rest.

div.stage: BILL hesitates a moment, then he stretches himself beside her, though he is careful not to touch her.
They lie there silently with open eyes, and they feel both their closeness and the distance that separates them.
After a while he raises his head on his arm and looks at her for a long time, as though he can see much more than just the outlines of her face.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Tell me about your dream.

div.stage: Bill says this, once more, as if she had been waiting for his invitation.
She holds out her hand to him, he takes it, and as he had often done before, he holds it and plays with her slender fingers, more absent- mindedly than tenderly.
ALICE sighs and begins to speak uncertainly.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I think it started in my parents house. They weren't there. I was alone. That surprised me because our wedding was the next day and I didn't have a wedding dress.

Then you and I were floating above a ancient city. It was a kind of crazy mix of ancient architectural styles. Oriental, Egyptian, Greek and Roman architecture. And it was completely deserted. The streets were empty - no people, no animals. And I remember thinking, so this is our honeymoon.

Then it was night and the sky was so full of stars, and so blue and wide it seemed like it was painted. You said it was the ceiling of our bridal chamber and you took me in your arms and made love to me and said you would love me forever.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I hope you loved me, too.

div.stage: BILL says this with an invisible, malicious smile.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Even more than you did me. We made love and it was wonderful, though there was a sadness to it, and a presentment of sorrow.
Suddenly it was morning and we were somewhere in the strange city.
We were still completely alone. But something terrible had happened - our clothes were gone. I was terrified as I had never been before, and felt such a burning shame that it almost consumed me.
At the same time I was furious with you because I thought it was your fault. And this sensation of terror, shame and fury was more intense than any emotion I had ever felt before.
You felt guilty and rushed away naked, to go and get clothes for us.
As soon as you were gone I felt wonderful. I neither felt sorry for you, or worried about you. It was heavenly to be alone.
I was lying in a lush garden, stretched out naked in the sunlight, and I was far more beautiful than I ever was in reality.
And while I lay there, a young man walked out of the woods. He was the young Naval officer I told you about from the hotel.
He looked different but I knew it was him. He stopped in front of me and looked at me searchingly.
I laughed seductively and wantonly, as I have never laughed in my life, and he held out his arms to me and sank down beside me.

div.stage: ALICE falls silent. BILLS throat is parched. In the darkness of the room he can see she has concealed her face in her hands.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: A strange dream, but that's not the end, is it?

div.stage: ALICE doesn't reply.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Was that the end?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Then why don't you tell me the rest of it?

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: It's not easy. Some things are not easy to say.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It's was only a dream.

div.stage: ALICE sighs and continues, hesitantly.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: He looked at me...and slowly took me in his arms...and we began making love.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I seemed to live through countless days and nights - there was neither time nor space. And the more we made love the more our hunger for each other increased.
And just as that earlier feeling of terror and shame went beyond anything I had ever felt, so nothing can be compared with the freedom and happiness and the..._desire_ that I now felt.
Then I realized there other couples around us - hundreds of them, and they too were making love.
Then I was making love to the other men, and as soon as my longing was satisfied with one, I wanted another.
I can't say how many I was with. And yet I didn't for one moment forget you. And all this time, you were buying the most beautiful clothes and jewellery you could find for me.

Then you were being followed by a crowd of people who were shouting threats. Then you were seized by soldiers, and there were also priests among them. Somebody - a gigantic person, tied your hands. You were still naked.
I knew you were going to be crucified but I felt no sympathy for you. I still blamed you for everything that had happened.
I felt that I was far removed from you but I knew you could see me naked in the arms of countless men in this sea of nakedness which foamed around me.
The soldiers began to whip you and blood flowed down you in streams. I saw it without feeling any surprise or pity.
Then you smiled at me as if to show you had fulfilled my wish and bought me everything I wanted. But I thought your actions were ridiculous and I wanted to make fun of you - to laugh in your face.

They began to nail you to the cross and I hoped that you would be able to hear my laughter. And so I laughed as shrill and loud as I could... That must have been the laugh that you heard when I woke up.

div.stage: Neither of them moves or says anything. Any remark at this moment would seem futile.
BILL realizes he is still holding ALICE'S hand.
She remains silent and motionless.
Ready as he is to hate her, his feeling of tenderness for these slender, cool fingers is unchanged except that it is more acute.
Involuntarily, he gently presses his lips on the familiar hand before he lets it go.
ALICE'S eyes are closed and there is the trace of a happy, innocent smile playing about her mouth.
He feels an incomprehensible desire to make love to her.
He rolls over and puts his arm around her but then checks himself.
He stretches himself out beside ALICE, who now seems asleep.
As he closes his eyes, he thinks:

sp.speaker: V.O.
sp.p: Whore of her dreams.

div.stage: There is now a sword between us.
We are lying here like mortal enemies.
HELENA'S BEDROOM On his way out he stops off in his daughter's room. She is asleep in her bed. He kisses her on the forehead.
STUDY He collects his costume and leaves.
He takes a cab to the Cafe Sonata where he met Nick Nightingale.
It is closed but he peers in through the window and sees the chairs are stacked on the tables and the place is being cleaned.
He taps on the glass.

set.p: After a couple of "we're closed" wave-offs from the manageress

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good morning. I'd like to have a quick word with the manager, if I may.

sp.speaker: CLEANING LADY
sp.p: Someone for you, Vicki.

sp.speaker: MANAGERESS
sp.p: Okay.

div.stage: Bill walks to the table she is seated at.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good morning.

sp.speaker: MANAGERESS
sp.p: What can I do for you?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It's very important that I get in touch with Nick Nightingale.

sp.speaker: MANAGERESS
sp.p: He'll be in tonight.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It's something I need to see him about this morning.

sp.speaker: MANAGERESS
sp.p: It's not our policy to give out employees addresses.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Of course. I completely understand. But I'm a doctor... (shows her his medical card) ...and this is a personal medical matter I know he'll want to know about as soon as possible.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good morning.

sp.speaker: DESK CLERK
sp.p: Good morning, sir. How can I help you?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Can you ring Mr. Nightingale's room for me, please?

div.stage: The DESK CLERK gives him a strange look.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nick Nightingale?

sp.speaker: DESK CLERK
sp.p: I'm sorry, sir, but he's checked out.

div.stage: The DESK CLERK has a slight, gay lisp.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: He checked out?

sp.speaker: DESK CLERK
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Did he leave a forwarding address?

sp.speaker: DESK CLERK
sp.p: No, I'm afraid not.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: When did he check out?

sp.speaker: DESK CLERK
sp.p: About five o'clock this morning.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Five o'clock. That's a pretty early check out, isn't it?

sp.speaker: DESK CLERK
sp.p: It is a little bit on the early side.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Did you happen to notice whether there was there anything strange about him when he left?

sp.speaker: DESK CLERK
sp.p: You aren't a detective, by any chance?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, I'm a doctor. Nick and I are old friends.

sp.speaker: DESK CLERK
sp.p: Well, since you ask, there _was_ something very strange about the way Mr. Nightingale left.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What was that?

sp.speaker: DESK CLERK
sp.p: Well, he came in at about four- thirty a.m. There were two men with him - _big-guys_.

div.stage: The DESK CLERK bends his elbows and clenches his fists to make a 'big-guy' gesture.

sp.speaker: DESK CLERK
sp.p: And I noticed he had a bruise on his cheek I'm sure he didn't have the night before.
The two men with him were
well-dressed and well-spoken, but they weren't the kind of people you'd want to fool around with, if you know what I mean.
Mr. Nightingale said he would be checking out and went up to his room with one of the men.
The other one stayed in the lobby and settled his bill, which was a couple of weeks overdue.
When they came down, I thought Mr. Nightingale looked...well - _scared_. Very scared, if you ask me.

He tried to pass me an envelope but they saw him and took it away and said any mail or messages for him would be collected by a person properly authorised to do so. When they took him outside, I could see there was a car waiting for them.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No idea where they might have gone?

sp.speaker: DESK CLERK
sp.p: None at all.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Ah-hhh, the good doctor.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good afternoon.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Did you enjoy your evening?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes, it was fine.

div.stage: BILL hands him the clothes. Gibson carefully takes the them out of the bag and lays them out on the counter to check them.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: I think you've forgotten the mask.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Oh - isn't it there?

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: It's not here. Maybe you left it at the partly.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I don't know. I must have lost it. Just put it on the bill.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Okay and if it turns up just bring it in and I'll give you a refund?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Fine.

div.stage: BILL watches as GIBSON writes up the bill.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I wonder if this might be a good time to have a word or two about your daughter?

div.stage: The question a peculiar expression about Gibson's nostrils.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: A word or two about my daughter?

div.stage: BILL speaks with outstretched fingers resting on the desk.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, it's just that last night I think you said that your daughter was not quite normal, mentally. The situation in which we found her certainly suggests something like that. And since I took part in it, or was at least a spectator, I feel I should recommend that you to get some medical advice.

div.stage: GIBSON smiles at BILL, insolently.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: And I suppose you yourself would like to take charge of the treatment?

div.stage: At this moment, a door which leads to one of the inner rooms opens, and a young man with a top-coat over his evening clothes steps out.
BILL recognises him as one of the KIMONO men from the night before.
He also catches a glimpse of the YOUNG GIRL, in bra and panties getting dressed, behind him before the door closes.
The KIMONO MAN seems taken aback when he sees BILL, but he regains his composure at once.
He lights a cigarette with a match from Gibson's counter, waves goodbye and leaves the shop.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: So that's how it is.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: What did you say?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Last night you were going to call the police.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: We've come to another arrangement.

set.p: Gibson slides the credit-card slip across the desk.

div.stage: BILL looks it over.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: Okay. It's a hundred and fifty for the basic rental. Two hundred for the inconvenience. Twenty five for the mask. And I've credited the three hundred deposit. Okay?
