div.stage: BILL nods.

sp.speaker: GIBSON
sp.p: And if the doctor should ever want anything again... (smiles) ...it needn't be a monk's costume.

div.stage: _Possible scene_.
BILL'S colleague, MAX
In addition to whatever else they may talk about, BILL says he feels a bit under the weather and asks MAX to take his appointments for the afternoon.

sp.speaker: V.O.
sp.p: To be written

div.stage: EXT VARIOUS POV'S DAY 59th street Bridge. L.I. Express way.
It stops a little past the house and BILL get out and walks to the gates.
The big gates are locked and there is no one in sight.
He hears the faint whine of the zoom lens motor on one of the surveillance cameras.
He looks up anxiously but is determined to carry out his inquiry.
He rings the bell mounted on one of the gate pillars.
He hears the motor on another surveillance camera, as it pans on to him.
He waits.
A few moments later, a car slowly approaches down the road from the house and stops at the gate.
An elderly servant gets out and walks slowly to the gate.
He holds a letter and without a word pushes it through the iron bars to BILL, whose heart is beating wildly.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: For me?

div.stage: The servant nods, walks back to the car and drives back up the road.
BILL looks at the envelope and sees: 'Dr. William Harford' written on it in a neat, dignified handwriting.
_How did they know his name_?
div.p: Give up your inquiries which are completely useless, and consider these words a second warning. We hope, for your own good, that this will be sufficient.
div.stage: BILL stands there looking at the note.

sp.speaker: V.O.
sp.p: Second warning -? Why the second warning - and not the last?.
The tone of the note was strangely reserved and seemed to show that the people who sent it by no means felt secure.
The note disappointed him, though, in a way, it reassured him, just why he couldn't say.
But, at least, he now felt the woman had come to no real harm, and that it
would be possible to find her if he went about it cautiously and cleverly.

div.stage: Some simple, natural dialog will be worked out for the action, over which the V.O. will be heard.

sp.speaker: V.O.
sp.p: He had gone home, feeling a little tired but surprisingly cheerful, with a strange sense of security, which somehow seemed deceptive.
He was in an excited and cheerful mood and he felt unusually fresh and clear in spite of spending the last two nights without sleep
At the same time, he felt that all this order, this normality, all the security of his existence, was nothing but deception and delusion.

div.p: And, he thought, there she sits with an angelic look, like a good wife and mother - the whore of her dreams who made love to a hundred men the preceding night and laughed when he was crucified, and to his surprise he didn't hate her.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Do you have to go out tonight?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm afraid so. I've got some patients to see in the hospital.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: How is Marion?

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.p: Only so-so.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I was hoping she would have begun to come to terms with things by now.

div.stage: Carl shakes his head..

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.p: She's taken it very hard. And when came for the body...it was just terrible.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I suppose her relatives are with her now?

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.p: No, they won't be coming until tonight. She'll be very glad to have some company. I'm taking her to stay with my mother in Connecticut tomorrow.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: That's probably just what she needs.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.p: Well, good to see you again. It's unbelievable how much there is to do to arrange a funeral.

div.stage: She is dressed in black. Her face becomes slightly flushed.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: You made me wait a long time.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm sorry, Marion. This was a particularly busy day for me.

div.stage: In the living room, Marion smiles and offers him a seat on the couch, sitting down next to him.
BILL takes her hand in his and looks at her warmly.
She makes little attempt to hide her desperate love.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I bumped into Carl downstairs. He said you're going to Connecticut tomorrow.

div.stage: She gazes into his eyes, mournfully.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: I won't go if you don't want me to.

div.stage: BILL gives her a long look, leans forward and kisses her on the lips.
They embrace and fall back on the couch.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Oh, Bill, I love you. I love you so much.

div.stage: He kisses her and starts to fondle her breasts and other regions.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Oh, Bill, I love you. I love you.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Marion.

div.stage: BILL just pronounces her name softly and continues to undo her clothes.
Then she begins to weep.
BILL tries to ignore this but she doesn't stop.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What's wrong?

div.stage: At first, MARION doesn't reply.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What's wrong?

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nothing.

div.stage: BILL sits up.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Martion, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Oh, Bill, it's just that it all seems so hopeless.

div.stage: BILL frowns.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: What's going to happen to us?

div.stage: This is definitely not what BILL had in mind and he looks away.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Are you angry with me for saying that?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, of course not.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: You are angry.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm not angry.

div.stage: She rests her chin on his shoulder.

sp.speaker: MARION
sp.p: Oh, Bill... Say something nice to me. I am so confused.

div.stage: BILL doesn't move.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Marion, I guess this _is_ crazy. I'm a happily married man with a child, and you are engaged to Carl.

div.stage: Marion's shoulders droop.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm sure the best thing for your to do is to go Connecticut tomorrow with Carl as you had planned. A complete change of environment and the fresh air will do you a world of good.

div.stage: Marion sits motionless and tears begin to stream down her face.
BILL sits in silence for a few moments, feeling impatience rather than sympathy.
Then he looks at his watch and gets to his feet.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Marion, my dear, much as I regret it...

div.stage: He would gladly say something kinder to her, but finds it difficult to do so.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: If we don't see each other before the wedding, let me offer you my most sincere congratulations and best wishes.

div.stage: She doesn't move, as though she understands neither his congratulations nor his farewell.
He holds out his hand but she refuses it, and he says almost reproachfully:

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I hope you'll keep in touch and let me know how you are.

div.stage: She sits there as if turned to stone.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Goodbye Marion.

div.stage: He leaves the room, stopping for a second in the doorway, as though giving her a last opportunity to call him back.
But she turns her head away.

set.p: EXT STREET - ON WAY TO DOMINO - NIGHT
INT/EXT BAKERY - BILL BUYS A CAKE - NIGHT
He carries a small cake-box tied with a blue ribbon.

div.stage: He finds the address and rings the bell. The buzzer sounds and he goes in.

sp.speaker: ARTY WOMAN
sp.p: Hi. What can I do for you?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good evening. I'm looking for Domino

sp.speaker: ARTY WOMAN
sp.p: Domino?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes. Is she in by any chance?

div.stage: An attractive girl in her twenties, wet hair and wrapped in a towel robe, pokes her head out.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: You're looking for Domino? You'll have to excuse the way I look. I just got out of the bath..

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes. Is she in?

div.stage: SALLY takes the door off the chain.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Come in for a minute.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Hi. I'm Sally. This is Pietra.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Well, as you can see, Domino's out.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Okay. Do you expect her back soon?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: I don't think so.

sp.speaker: ARTY WOMAN
sp.p: Maybe tomorrow.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Okay. Well, I'll just leave this cake for her, if I may.

sp.speaker: ARTY WOMAN
sp.p: Okay. Great. We'll see that she gets it.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Is she out of town?

sp.speaker: ARTY WOMAN
sp.p: Uh--no, actually, she's in the hospital.

div.stage: Sally gives her a look.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that. I hope it's nothing serious.

sp.speaker: ARTY WOMAN
sp.p: We're not really sure. It was for some kind of tests.

div.stage: Sally gives her another look and moves close to BILL, her towel robe parting a little to show her naked underneath.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Listen, I'm not sure what's was on your mind but if it was more than cake, there's nothing wrong with me.

div.stage: BILL hesitates.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Look, I'd love to but some other time. Okay? I was just passing by with the cake.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: You sure?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I've really got to go.

set.p: EXT DOMINO STREET - BILL WALKING - NIGHT

sp.speaker: V.O.
sp.p: Was this another and final sign that everything he put his hand to was bound to turn out a failure for him?
But why should it be. Wasn't the fact that he had just escaped a possibly fatal infection from the girl a good sign?
Everything now seemed so unreal; his home, his wife, his child, his profession, and even himself.
Bill felt choked with tears. He had not slept for two days and his nerves were gradually giving way.
He intentionally struck up a quicker pace than he was in the mood for.

div.stage: Suddenly, BILL feels he is being followed.
He glances back and sees a man about half a block behind him walking at the same rapid pace.
As soon as the man notices BILL has seen him, he stops and looks in a shop window.

set.p: SHORT SEQUENCE OF THE MAN FOLLOWING BILL - SEVERAL

div.stage: He looks back again.
The man is still there, walking slowly towards him.
BILL goes into a nearby Coffee Bar.
A waitress comes over with a glass of ice water and a plastic menu.

sp.speaker: WAITRESS
sp.p: Hi. Would you like to order now?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Sure.

div.stage: BILL manages a tired smile and looks at the menu.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'll have...a cup of coffee and...maybe a cheese Danish.

sp.speaker: WAITRESS
sp.p: Okay, great.

div.stage: She leaves, taking away the menu.
BILL opens his eyes as wide as possible, arches his neck and drinks some water. He looks terrible.
He idly picks up the newspaper he just bought and starts to look through it.
div.p: EX-BEAUTY QUEEN IN HOTEL DRUGS OVERDOSE Kelly Curran, 30, a former Miss Wisconsin, was taken to New York Hospital this morning in critical condition after taking a drugs overdose. She was found unconscious when police broke into her room at the San Carlos hotel after she failed to respond to efforts to contact her. The night manager told police she had returned to the hotel at four o'clock in the morning accompanied by two unidentified men.

sp.speaker: V.O.
sp.p: Four o'clock in the morning! The same time he returned home!

div.p: Wasn't it two men who took Nick Nightingale from his hotel only an hour later?
There was no compelling reason to believe that Kelly Curran and a certain other woman were one and the same. And yet - his heart throbbed and his hand trembled.
div.stage: BILL looks for the waitress to get his check.
At the same time, he notices the man who had been following him sitting at another table.
The man slowly raises a newspaper, partly covering his face.
BILL pays his check.
At the door, he turns to look for the suspicious character at the table but he is already gone.
INT HOSPITAL
BILL the signs to the Emergency Room Waiting Area.
He walks up a young black woman at the information desk.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good evening, I'm Doctor Harford. I'd like to see a patient of mine who I believe was admitted this morning.

div.stage: He shows her his identity card.

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Okay, thanks, Doctor. What did you say the name was?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Curran, Kelly Curran.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Yes.

div.stage: The woman keyboards the letters into her computer.
Something comes up on her screen that makes her stop.

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Kelly Curran, right?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: That's right.

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: I'm sorry, doctor, but I'm afraid she died this afternoon.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: CLERK
sp.p: Yes, at three-forty five, p.m.

div.stage: BILL stares at her.
He feels strangely relieved.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Is the body in the hospital morgue?

div.stage: INT HOSPITAL CORRIDOR ON WAY TO MORGUE
BILL follows a black male orderly down a hospital corridor.
INT MORGUE The morgue is a brightly lit, white-tiled room with six autopsy tables and fifty numbered crypts.
There is no one else working in the room.
The black orderly checks a slip of paper and goes to that crypt.
He opens the door, slides out the pallet and pulls down the sheet covering the body.
BILL stares down at the naked body of a young woman.
The orderly gives BILL an inquiring look. BILL nods and the orderly crosses the room and lights a cigarette.
BILL lifts the woman's head a little.

set.p: Her face is white. Her half-closed eyes stare at him. The lower jaw

div.stage: He gently lays her head back on the pallet.
His eyes follow the lines of her body.
He touches her forehead and her cheeks, her shoulders and her arms, doing so as if compelled and directed to by an invisible power.
He twines his fingers about those of the corpse, and rigid as they are, they seem to make an effort to move, to seize his hand.
He bends over her, as if magically attracted.

sp.speaker: V.O.
sp.p: Was this the woman he was seeking?
Were these the eyes that had shone at him the day before with so much passion?
Was this the alluring body for which, only yesterday, he had felt such agonising desire?
He bent lower, as if he could extract an answer from the rigid features.
But he had only seen her face for an instant, and he knew that if it were _her_ face, and _her_ eyes, he would not, could not - and in reality did not want to know.
He also realized that from the time he
read the account in the newspaper, he had imagined her as having the features of his wife.
And he shuddered to realise that his wife had constantly been in his mind's eye as the woman he had been seeking.

div.stage: He frees his fingers from those of the corpse, and taking her thin wrists, places the ice cold arms alongside the body very carefully.
He looks at the orderly.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Okay - thanks. I'm finished.

div.stage: Bill watches the orderly slide the pallet back into the crypt and close the door.

sp.speaker: ORDERLY
sp.p: Want to wash up, Doc?

div.stage: He gestures to a row of sinks.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Thanks.

div.stage: BILL goes over and carefully washes his hands with disinfectant.
His cellular phone goes off.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Hello... Yes... That's perfectly all right... Okay... Oh, I guess about twenty minutes... Okay... Goodbye.

div.stage: The butler opens the door and takes BILL's coat.
Ziegler's assistant, HARRIS, appears.

sp.speaker: HARRIS
sp.p: Good evening, Dr. Harford.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Good evening.

sp.speaker: HARRIS
sp.p: Thank you for coming over so quickly.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What seems to be the problem?

sp.speaker: HARRIS
sp.p: I'm afraid I don't know. Will you follow me, please?

div.stage: BILL follows HARRIS. Their footsteps sound loud in the quiet house.
They stop in front of the library door and HARRIS knocks.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Come in.

div.stage: HARRIS opens the door for BILL and closes it behind him, remaining outside.
ZIEGLER gets up from an armchair and shakes hands.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Hi, Bill. Sorry to drag you over here at this time of night.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No problem.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: What are you drinking?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, I suppose a brandy would be nice.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: It was lovely to see you and Alice the other night.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It was a wonderful party and we had a great time.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: It's a shame you had to leave so early.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: We hated to go but I had a couple of early appointments.

div.stage: ZIEGLER hands him his brandy and they touch glasses.

sp.speaker: BOTH
sp.p: Cheers.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nice..

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Napoleon, 1935.

div.stage: BILL looks suitably impressed.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: So - what seems to be the problem? Someone under the weather?

div.stage: ZIEGLER looks into his brandy glass.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Can I be frank, Bill?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: I'm afraid what I've got to say is a bit awkward to talk about.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I'm your doctor.

div.stage: ZIEGLER rotates his brandy.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: This isn't a medical problem.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Oh.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: No.

div.stage: BILL looks at him, quizzically.
ZIEGLER nods and returns a tense smile.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: I'm not exactly sure how to begin this. But maybe the best thing is to just to put the cards on the table and say that I happen to know quite a lot about what you've been doing for the past twenty-four hours.

div.stage: He lets this sink in

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Sorry, Victor but may I ask what the hell are you're talking about?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Bill, please believe me, I know this is awkward - perhaps as awkward for me as it is for you. Okay?

div.stage: Bill says nothing.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Okay?... Now, the reason I wanted to talk to you is that I think you may be harbouring one or two misapprehensions about last night, which I would like to clear up.

div.stage: Silence

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Okay. I think I should also tell you that I was there. At the house.

set.p: ZIEGLER says this in a very matter-of-fact way.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: I saw everything that happened.

div.stage: A long pause.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Well, what an amazing coincidence.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: The words practically right out of my mouth. An amazing coincidence. That's what I first thought. But then I remembered seeing you and your musician friend, Nick, renewing old acquaintances at the party, and it didn't take me very long to realize that the rotten little prick was the reason you were there.

div.stage: Bill gets to his feet. There's no point in denying anything and he has to protect Nick.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Look, Victor, this was all my fault. Nick did his best to talk me out of it.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Yes, I know. He told us. But the fact remains that the little cocksucker told you in the first place and gave you the password and the address.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: It was all down to me pressurising him.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Maybe so, but I recommended him to these people and he betrayed my trust.

div.stage: BILL hesitates.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I went to his hotel this morning.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: I know.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: That was my man following you. He told me you spotted him.

div.stage: BILL shakes his head incredulously.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Why did you have me followed?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: For your own good? To avoid any foolishness?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: The hotel clerk said two men took him away at five-thirty this morning.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: That's right. They gave him an airline ticket and took him to the airport. By now he's probably back with his family in Seattle.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: The clerk said he had a bruise on his cheek.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Is he okay?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: He's a lot better than he deserves to be.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nothing else?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: He's okay. Phone him in Seattle if you're concerned. I'll give you his phone number.

div.stage: ZIEGLER pours more brandy.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Nick never said anything about a second password. Was that what gave me away?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: There was no second password. You gave yourself away as soon as you arrived. Invited guests come in limos not taxis, and they don't get out of their cars half a block from the gate.

After the servants took your coat, one of our people went through your pockets and found the receipt for the rented tux and cassock made out to Doctor W. Harford, a name obviously not on the guest list.

div.stage: ZIEGLER sips some brandy.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Bill, these were not just _ordinary_ people. I don't think you have any idea how fortunate you are to have got out of that situation as easily as you did. Someday you can thank me for that.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What about the woman?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Not at all what you think.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Why did she try to warn me?

div.stage: ZIEGLER doesn't answer immediately.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Why was she willing to sacrifice herself for me?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Bill, are you so sure she was the kind of woman for whom the things you imagined were actually a sacrifice?
If she attended these affairs and knew the rules so well, do you suppose it would have made any difference to her whether she belonged to one of the men, or to all of them?
Bill, she was just a thousand-a-night- hooker - no more, no less.

div.stage: BILL stares at him blankly.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: Bill, tell me, did you never consider the possibility that the whole thing might have been nothing more than a charade?... A charade played out for the benefit of someone who didn't belong - to frighten them and make sure they keep quiet?

div.stage: BILL takes a deep breath and tries to absorb what he has just been told
Then takes the newspaper from his pocket with the story about the drugs overdose.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What about this?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: What about it?

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Is it her? I went to the morgue but I couldn't tell.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: It is her.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Is this what she meant when she aid she would redeem me?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: No - it wasn't But I was afraid you might think it was, and that's why I wanted to see you.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: You say it was a charade but isn't a but strange, a woman offers herself as a sacrifice and the next morning she's dead?

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: That _was_ a coincidence. An amazing coincidence, perhaps but a genuine coincidence, nonetheless.

Bill, please believe me, nothing happened to her that hadn't happened before. She got a lot of attention, that was certainly true, but nothing she didn't want. And later, when my people left her at the hotel, they said everything was absolutely okay.
What then happened in her room, she did to herself, as she had done many times before. But, sadly, this would be the last time.
She OD'd on crack, like the papers said. No chance for foul play. Her door was locked from the _inside_ and the police had to break it down.
No, I'm afraid for her it was always going to be just a matter of time - you said as much yourself when she passed out in my bedroom at the Christmas party.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: My God, was that her?

div.stage: ZIEGLER nods, yes.
Several moments of strained silence go by.

set.p: Then ZIEGLER stands up with a comfortable end-of-conversation-sigh.

sp.speaker: ZIEGLER
sp.p: So, Bill, I hope you understand why I thought it was important to tidy this up. But now I think all the dishes are washed and put away. Nobody killed anybody. Someone died. That's sad. But life goes on. It always does. Until it doesn't. Okay?

div.stage: He hears ALICE breathing softly and regularly and sees the outline of her head on the pillow.
Unexpectedly, his heart is filled with a feeling of tenderness and even of security.
Then he notices something dark quite near ALICE'S face.
It has definite outlines like the shadowy features of a human face, and it is lying on his pillow.
For a moment his heart stops beating, but an instant later he sees what it is, and stretching out his hand, picks up the MASK he had worn the night before.

sp.speaker: V.O.
sp.p: He thought he must have dropped it in the morning when he packed the costume away, and Alice had found it and placed it on the pillow beside her, as though it signified _his_ face, the face of a husband who had become an enigma to her.

div.stage: All at once he reaches the end of his strength. Clutching the mask, he utters a loud and painful
sob - quite unexpectedly - and sinks down beside the bed, buries his head in the pillows, and cries.
A minute later he feels a soft hand caressing his hair.
He looks into ALICE'S worried eyes.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: I will tell you everything.

div.stage: ALICE raises her hand, as if to stop him, but he takes it and holds it.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: No, I will tell you everything.

div.stage: ALICE sits expressionlessly at a small table near the window, finishing a cigarette. A full ashtray next to her.
BILL sits miserably on the edge of the bed staring at the carpet..
He sighs and looks at Alice.
She smiles at him sadly and reaches out her hand.
He gets up slowly and goes over to her.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: What are we going to do now?

div.stage: She gazes into his eyes.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: I think we should both be grateful that we have come unharmed out of all our adventures, whether they were real or only a dream.

div.stage: BILL kneels down in front of her.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Are you really sure that?

div.stage: She takes his hands in hers and looks at them.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: Only as sure as I am that the reality of one night, let alone that of a whole lifetime, is not the whole truth.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: And no dream is entirely a dream.

div.stage: She presses his head to her breast.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: But I think we're awake now.. And for a long time to come.

sp.speaker: BILL
sp.p: Forever.

div.stage: Almost before he finishes the word, ALICE lays her fingers on his lips.

sp.speaker: ALICE
sp.p: We should never look into the future.

div.stage: They kiss tenderly and lie down on the bed, dozing a little, dreamlessly, close to one another - until with the usual noises from the street, and a victorious ray of sunlight through the opening of the curtain, there is a knock on the door and their seven-year-old daughter, HELENA, runs into the room and, laughing, jumps into their bed. And a new day begins.
